[empathetically] Being thousands of miles away makes it harder to, [pause], show you how much I genuinely respect your work beyond just loving you.

[angry] So you just, um, went behind my back and used your, like, [loudly], connections to get me a pity meeting that I didn't, well, [hurt], earn on my own merit? I mean, that's exactly what I was afraid of!

But um, how am I supposed to know if, like, [uncertain], any success I might have is real or just, well, [whispering], because I'm dating someone famous who, umm, [sigh], pulled strings for me?
[very sincerely] Because, um, I've watched you pour your soul into every page for, like, [proud], three years now, and well, talent like yours doesn't need my name attached to succeed.

I don't know if I can, um, believe that when everyone will think, like, [melancholic], I only got published because of who I'm with, not because I actually, well, [very sad], deserve it on my own. [long pause]

Look, I mean, the meeting is yours to take or leave, but um, [rationally], my editor has rejected work from my own friends before, so like, [honest], she wouldn't waste her time if she didn't see real potential in you.
[crying while speaking] Um, I just—[gasp]
I know being apart makes you, um, doubt yourself more, but like, [loving], I see your brilliance even from across the ocean. I mean, that's never changed.
[relieved] Maybe you're right.
Take the meeting and let your work, [determined], speak for itself—that's all I'm, [supportive], asking you to do.
[trembling] Okay, um, I'll take the meeting, but like, [hopeful], only if she truly doesn't know about us, because I mean, I need this to be mine.
It already is yours, every beautiful, [tender], word of it, and soon everyone else will, [smile], know that too.
